discoveredAssets: localhost:80 - Blog application (Apache 2.4.54, PHP 7.4.33) - Port 80, Multiple blog posts with categories
Admin Login Panel - Authentication form at /admin.php - POST-based login, error messages indicate valid credentials required
Homepage (/) - Blog home page displaying posts with category filtering - GET parameter 'category' available
Category Filter Endpoint (?category=) - Dynamic blog post filtering by categories (Nature, Tech, Cooking, Photography, Health) - Potential SQL injection
Styles.css - Application stylesheet at /styles.css - Static CSS resource (200 OK)
Images Directory (/images/) - Blog post images directory - 403 Forbidden access
Security Headers - Server discloses Apache 2.4.54 and PHP 7.4.33 versions; Missing X-Frame-Options, CSP, HSTS, X-Content-Type-Options headers

targets.objective: Test admin authentication for vulnerabilities including SQL injection in login form, default credentials, session management, brute force resistance, CSRF token presence, and privilege escalation
targets.rationale: Admin panel is a critical entry point. Testing for authentication bypass (SQLi, NoSQLi, default credentials), CSRF vulnerabilities, and post-authentication functionality if access is gained

targets.objective: Test category parameter for SQL injection (UNION-based, time-based blind, error-based), NoSQL injection, and other injection attacks. Verify database backend and extract schema/data
targets.rationale: Differential response testing showed 11 results with injection payload vs 3 with normal query, indicating potential SQL injection vulnerability. This is a CRITICAL finding requiring deep exploitation testing

targets.objective: Test homepage for XSS vulnerabilities via category parameter, CSRF attacks on form submission, authorization issues, and client-side injection vectors
targets.rationale: Primary attack surface with user-controllable input. Category parameter does not appear to sanitize or escape special characters

targets.objective: Test for HTTP methods (PUT, DELETE, PATCH), path traversal via category parameter, file inclusion attacks, directory traversal, and other server-level vulnerabilities
targets.rationale: Missing security headers indicate potentially outdated or misconfigured server. Apache 2.4.54 and PHP 7.4.33 may have known vulnerabilities requiring version-specific exploit testing

keyFindings: [CRITICAL] SQL Injection vulnerability detected in category parameter - Injection payload (category=Nature' OR '1'='1) returns 11 results instead of 3, indicating WHERE clause bypass and potential database extraction capability
[HIGH] Admin login panel at /admin.php lacks CSRF token protection in form - Vulnerable to Cross-Site Request Forgery attacks
[HIGH] Missing critical security headers (X-Frame-Options, Content-Security-Policy, HSTS, X-Content-Type-Options) - Application vulnerable to clickjacking and header-based attacks
[HIGH] Server version disclosure - Apache 2.4.54 and PHP 7.4.33 versions exposed in response headers, enabling version-specific exploit research
[MEDIUM] Images directory (403 Forbidden) restricts direct access but images are referenced in posts - Potential information disclosure if directory listing is enabled
[MEDIUM] PHP error reporting enabled - PHP notices visible in HTML output indicating debug information leakage
[LOW] No robots.txt or sitemap.xml discovered - Indicates manual endpoint discovery likely required
